statement.text: Aortic dissection classically presents with sudden, severe, 'tearing' or 'ripping' chest or back pain that may migrate as the dissection propagates. Additional findings may include pulse deficits, blood pressure differentials between arms, new aortic regurgitation murmur, or malperfusion syndromes affecting end organs. However, presentation varies widely and dissection should be considered in any high-risk patient with sudden severe chest/back pain.
statement.formal: Classic Presentation: Sudden onset severe tearing/ripping pain (chest, back, or interscapular) + One or more of: Pulse deficit | BP differential >20 mmHg | Aortic regurgitation | Malperfusion (stroke, limb ischemia, abdominal) | Hypotension/shock

explanation.intuition: When the aorta tears, patients often describe it as the worst pain of their life, sudden and tearing. The pain location tracks the dissection: ascending involvement causes anterior chest pain, descending causes back pain. As the false lumen expands, it can compress or obstruct branch arteries, explaining why some patients present with stroke, cold leg, or abdominal symptoms rather than just pain.
explanation.key_insight: Aortic dissection is a great imitator - it can present as MI, stroke, acute abdomen, or limb ischemia. The key is to think of dissection in any high-risk patient (hypertensive, connective tissue disease, cocaine use) with sudden severe pain, especially if they have 'something else' (abnormal pulse, new murmur, or focal neuro deficit). Missing the diagnosis is often fatal.
explanation.technical_details: Pain characteristics: Described as 'tearing' or 'ripping' in ~50%, abrupt maximal onset in ~85%. Location reflects anatomy: Type A = anterior chest, Type B = interscapular/back. Migration of pain suggests propagating dissection. Malperfusion syndromes by vessel: (1) Arch branches → stroke, syncope; (2) Coronary → MI (usually RCA/right coronary); (3) Intercostal/spinal → paraplegia; (4) Mesenteric → bowel ischemia; (5) Renal → oliguria, hypertension; (6) Iliac → limb ischemia. Physical findings: BP differential >20 mmHg (30%), pulse deficit (30%), aortic regurgitation murmur (32% of Type A).
common_misconceptions: Dissection always causes tearing chest pain - presentation varies widely
Normal chest X-ray rules out dissection - only 80% have widened mediastinum
All dissection patients are hypertensive - some present with hypotension
Negative troponin excludes dissection - coronary malperfusion can cause MI in dissection

definitions_glossary.pulse_deficit: Absent or diminished pulse in one extremity compared to others
definitions_glossary.malperfusion: Inadequate blood supply to organs due to branch vessel compromise
definitions_glossary.aortic_regurgitation: Backflow through aortic valve, can be caused by Type A dissection
definitions_glossary.dynamic_obstruction: Intermittent branch vessel compression by mobile intimal flap
definitions_glossary.static_obstruction: Fixed branch vessel compromise by extending dissection

malperfusion_syndromes.manifestation: Stroke, TIA, syncope, altered mental status
Abdominal pain, bloody stool, lactate elevation

definition.@value: Signs, symptoms, and clinical features of acute aortic dissection

sources.citation: Hagan PG, et al. The International Registry of Acute Aortic Dissection (IRAD). JAMA. 2000;283(7):897-903.
2010 ACCF/AHA Guidelines for Thoracic Aortic Disease

learning_objectives: Recognize the classic presentation of aortic dissection
Identify malperfusion syndromes and their territories
List differential diagnoses for sudden severe chest/back pain
clinical_pearls: Sudden, severe, maximal-at-onset pain is the hallmark
Any patient with 'MI + stroke' or 'MI + limb ischemia' = think dissection
BP differential >20 mmHg between arms is highly suggestive
Don't give thrombolytics for suspected ACS without ruling out dissection
